div.p: This site provides information using PDF, visit this link to download the Adobe Acrobat Reader DC software.

This message is to provide an update on the PCSC eLearning schedule for the remainder of the school year.Â PCSC will remain having eLearning in the month of May on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays through May 22.Â Additionally, Tuesday, May 5 will be an eLearning Day in order to ensure we reach 160 instructional days for this academic year.

p.a: Read or Print the May eLearning Day Calendar Here.

div.p: The week of May 26 may have some coordinated virtual celebrations or events from each school; however, the last eLearning day of the year will be Friday, May 22.
Information about other dates or celebrations and the various ways in which schools will be incorporating these into the school year will be communicated as soon as decisions are made.

To those who may have traveled to another state for spring break or another reason and who may have returned or may soon be returning, the Marshall County Health Department and Marshall County Emergency Management is asking you to self-quarantine for 14 days once you arrive back to the area.Â

The Center for Disease Control does not generally issue advisories or restrictions for travel within the United States. However, cases of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) have been reported in many states, and some areas are experiencing community spread of the disease. Crowded travel settings, like airports, may increase chances of getting COVID-19, if there are other travelers with coronavirus infection. There are several things folks should consider when deciding whether it is safe for them to travel and upon returning home.Â

li.strong: Is COVID-19 spreading in the area where youâre going?
li.br: If COVID-19 is spreading at your destination, but not where you live, you may be more likely to get infected if you travel there than if you stay home. If you have questions about your destination, you should check your destinationâs local health department website for more information.

li.strong: Will you or your travel companion(s) be in close contact with others during your trip?
li.br: Your risk of exposure to respiratory viruses like coronavirus may increase in crowded settings, particularly closed-in settings with little air circulation. This may include settings such as conferences, public events (like concerts and sporting events), religious gatherings, public spaces (like movie theatres and shopping malls), and public transportation (like buses, metro, trains).

li.strong: Are you or your travel companion(s) more likely to get severe illness if you get COVID-19?
li.br: People at higher risk for severe disease areÂ older adults and people of any age with serious chronic medical conditionsÂ (such as heart disease, lung disease, or diabetes). CDC recommends thatÂ travelers at higher risk for COVID-19 complicationsÂ avoid all cruise travel and nonessential air travel.

li.strong: Do you have a plan for taking time off from work or school, in case you are told to stay home for 14 days for self-monitoring or if you get sick with COVID-19?
li.br: If you have close contact with someone with COVID-19 during travel, you may be asked to stay home to self-monitor and avoid contact with others for up to 14 days after travel. If you become sick with COVID-19, you may be unable to go to work or school until youâre considered noninfectious. You will be asked to avoid contact with others (including being in public places) during this period of infectiousness.

li.strong: Do you live with someone who is older or has a serious, chronic medical condition?
li.br: If you get sick with COVID-19 upon your return from travel, your household contacts may be at risk of infection. Household contacts who areÂ older adults or persons of any age with severe chronic medical conditionsÂ are at higher risk for severe illness from COVID-19.

li.strong: Is COVID-19 spreading where I live when I return from travel?
li.br: Consider the risk of passing COVID-19 to others during travel, particularly if you will be in close contact with people who areÂ older adults or have severe chronic health conditionÂ These people are at higher risk of getting very sick. If your symptoms are mild or you donât have a fever, you may not realize you are infectious.

div.p: Governor Holcomb announced today that all schools in the State of Indiana are closed until May 1.Â In response to this, the information that follows includes how Plymouth Community School Corporation is going to schedule eLearning through May 1.Â Spring Break begins tomorrow and ends Monday, March 30.Â eLearning will resume on Wednesday, April 1 and will continue every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday through May 1.Â There will be no eLearning on Friday, April 10 as this is Good Friday and was originally not on our corporation calendar.
Additionally, all activities and events are cancelled through May 1.

Our sack lunch option has been helpful for many.Â We will continue offering lunches for our students through Spring Break and during the weeks of closure through May 1.Â Beginning Friday, March 20 along with every weekday during Spring Break and every weekday that follows through May 1, lunches can be picked up between 11 a.m. and 1p.m. at Door 1 at Plymouth High School only.Â There is no charge for these lunches.Â If these times do not work for you yet this is still a need, please call 936-3115 and we will work with you.Â We do not want any of our students going without food during this time.
All of this information will be available on our website and will be posted on social media.

We appreciate everyoneâs understanding and patience during this time.Â If you are in need of any support or resources, you can call 211 or we have a listing of resources on our website, or feel free to call your childâs school or the Administration building and someone will assist you.

hr.p: 20 de marzo de 2020
Estimadas familias:

El gobernador Holcomb anunciÃ³ ayer que todas las escuelas del estado de Indiana permanecerÃ¡n cerradas hasta el 1o de mayo. En respuesta a esto, la informaciÃ³n que sigue incluye cÃ³mo el Distrito Escolar de la Comunidad de Plymouth programarÃ¡ el aprendizaje electrÃ³nico hasta el 1o de mayo. Las vacaciones de primavera comenzaron hoy hasta el lunes, 30 de marzo. El aprendizaje electrÃ³nico reanudarÃ¡ el miÃ©rcoles, 1o de abril y continuarÃ¡ todos los lunes, miÃ©rcoles y viernes hasta el 1o de mayo. No habrÃ¡ aprendizaje electrÃ³nico el viernes, 10 de abril, como es Viernes Santo.
AdemÃ¡s, todas las actividades y eventos todavÃ­a estÃ¡n cancelados hasta el 1o de mayo.

Nuestra opciÃ³n de almuerzo ha sido una gran ayuda para muchos. AsÃ­ que, continuaremos ofreciendo almuerzos para nuestros estudiantes empezando el viernes, 20 de marzo, todos los dÃ­as durante las vacaciones de primavera y todos los dÃ­as de la semana hasta el 1o de mayo almuerzos se pueden recoger entre las 11:00 de la maÃ±ana hasta las 1:00 de la tarde solamente en Plymouth High School por yendo a puerta no. 1. El almuerzo para su estudiante es gratis. Si esas horas no funcionan para usted y todavÃ­a es una necesidad, llame al 936-3115 y trabajaremos con usted. No queremos que ninguno de nuestros estudiantes pase sin comida durante este tiempo.
Toda esta informaciÃ³n estarÃ¡ disponible en nuestro sitio web y se publicarÃ¡ en las redes sociales.

Agradecemos la comprensiÃ³n y la paciencia de todos durante este tiempo. Si necesita ayuda o recursos, puede llamar al 211 o tenemos una lista de recursos en nuestro sitio web, o no dude en llamar a la escuela de su hijo o al edificio de AdministraciÃ³n y alguien lo ayudarÃ¡.
Gracias,
Andy Hartley, Superintendente

hr.h3: Superintendent's letter regarding school closings and other important information
hr.p:
Â
Dear Plymouth Community School Corporation Families,
Â
I am writing as a follow-up to our recently announced school closings.

First, I would like to apologize if you did not receive the initial call that made our announcement.Â We are looking into this and hope to have that remedied. Â
Â
School Closure Information:
All PCSC schools are closed Monday, March 16.

eLearning will begin on Tuesday, March 17 and continue through Thursday, March 19.
Â
All scheduled activities, practices, or events are cancelled through the end of Spring Break.
Â
As a reminder, the PCSC Spring Break begins Friday, March 20 and will last through Monday, March 30. Â

As of now, each school office and the corporation office will be open during normal school hours Monday through Thursday of this coming week.Â If you need to pick up any of your childâs materials from school (iPad, instruments, etc), please call your respective schoolâs office to make those arrangements. Â
We will continue to monitor and evaluate the overall situation as it relates to our status after Spring Break.Â As decisions are made, they will be communicated to you.

The days we are closed without eLearning will not need to be made up at the end of the year.Â
Food Service Information:
School lunches are still going to be offered as a takeout option for any student Monday through Thursday of next week.Â They will be sack lunches and will be available for pickup at the following locations from 11:00 a.m. to 1:30 p.m.

You may stop at any of these locations, even if it isnât your childâs school.Â If these times do not work for you yet this is still a need, please call the number next to the school from which you intend to get the sack lunches and we will work with you. Â
You will receive enough lunches for each PCSC student in your household to have a lunch for the remainder of what would have been the school week.
Those students who participate in the Cultivate or Blessings in a Backpack program will be contacted in order to arrange for your child to receive those resources.

p.br:
We will continue to monitor the overall situation through numerous communications from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), as well as the Indiana State Department of Health, Indiana Department of Education, the Marshall County Health Department, and Saint Joseph Health Systems. Â
Â
Everyone with whom we speak and every message we receive is communicating that the best preventive measure anyone can take is to practice good hygiene.Â This is something that is continuously communicated.Â The most effective practices include the following:

hr.p:
1.Â Â Â Wash our hands often with soap and water.Â If soap and water are not available, then use a hand sanitizer.
2.Â Â Â Cover our mouths and nose when coughing or sneezing.Â Doing so into our elbows is the best way to do this.
3.Â Â Â Avoid touching our eyes, nose, or mouth as germs are often spread after touching something that is contaminated and then touching our eyes, nose, or mouth.
4.Â Â Â Avoid close contact with people who are ill.Â This also includes our responsibility to stay at home or have our kids stay at home if they are sick.
5.Â Â Â Practice social distancing and avoid gatherings of 250 or more.
Please know that we have an excellent janitorial staff who has already been doing more during this flu season trying to ensure common touch areas are cleaned and disinfected regularly.Â This will continue.Â Additionally, our bus drivers throughout the past week disinfected their buses after each dayâs route. Â
Â
Additionally, with Spring Break approaching, if you are still planning to travel, we just ask that you are aware of the locations with specific travel recommendations from the CDC.
Â
In conclusion, please know that we will continue to monitor this and will maintain communication with our local health experts.Â If other necessary information becomes available, we will be sure to communicate with you.
Â
Sincerely,
Andy Hartley, Superintendent

Estimadas familias del Distrito Escolar de la Comunidad de Plymouth,
Â
Estoy escribiendo como un seguimiento de nuestro cerramiento de escuelas recientemente anunciado.
Â
Primero, me gustarÃ­a disculparme si no recibiÃ³ la llamada inicial que se enviÃ³. Estamos investigando esto y esperamos corregirlo.
Â
Cierre de escuela informaciÃ³n:
Todas nuestras escuelas estÃ¡n cerradas el lunes, 16 de marzo

Â El aprendizaje electrÃ³nico comenzarÃ¡ el martes, 17 de marzo y continuarÃ¡ hasta el jueves, 19 de marzo.
Â
Todas las actividades, prÃ¡cticas, entrenamientos o eventos programados despuÃ©s de la escuela estÃ¡n cancelados hasta despuÃ©s de las vacaciones de primavera.
Â
Recordatorio que las vacaciones de primavera comienzan el viernes, 20 de marzo hasta el lunes, 30 de marzo. Â
Â
Hasta ahora, cada oficina escolar y la oficina del distrito estarÃ¡ abierta durante el horario escolar normal de lunes a jueves de esta semana. Si necesita recoger algÃºn material (iPad, instrumentos, etc.), llame a la oficina de su escuela para hacer esos arreglos. Cada oficina escolar y la oficina del distrito estarÃ¡n abiertos durante el horario escolar normal de lunes a jueves la prÃ³xima semana.

Continuaremos observando y evaluando la situaciÃ³n general en lo que se refiere a nuestro estado despuÃ©s de las vacaciones de primavera.Â A medida que se tomen las decisiones, seÂ comunicarÃ¡n con usted.
Los dÃ­as en que escuela se cancelÃ³ sin tener dÃ­as de aprendizaje electrÃ³nico no tendrÃ¡n que ser recuperados al final del aÃ±o escolar.
Â
InformaciÃ³n de Alimentos
Los almuerzos escolares todavÃ­a se ofrecerÃ¡n como comida para llevar para todos estudiantes de lunes a jueves la prÃ³xima semana. La comida para llevar estarÃ¡ disponible para recoger en los siguientes lugares de las 11:00 a.m.-1:30 p.m.
Â

Â
Si esas horas no funciona para usted y todavÃ­a es una necesidad, favor de llamar al nÃºmero de la escuela donde usted quiere obtener los almuerzos y trabajaremos con usted. No queremos que ninguno de nuestros estudiantes pase sin comida durante este tiempo.
Familias recibirÃ¡n suficientes almuerzos para cada estudiante que asiste nuestras escuelas.
Los estudiantes que participan en el programa Cultivar o Blessings in a Backpack se contactaran para que su hijo/a reciba esos recursos.

p.br:
Continuaremos observando la situaciÃ³n general a travÃ©s de numerosas comunicaciones de los Centros para el Control y la PrevenciÃ³n de Enfermedades (CDC), asÃ­ como del Departamento de Salud del Estado de Indiana, el Departamento de EducaciÃ³n de Indiana, el Departamento de Salud del Condado de Marshall y Saint Joseph Health Systems.
Â
Todas las personas con quienes hablamos y cada mensaje que recibimos estÃ¡n comunicando que la mejor medida para reducir la propagaciÃ³n de enfermedades es practicar buena higiene. Esto es algo que es comunicado continuamente. Las prÃ¡cticas mÃ¡s efectivas incluyen lo siguiente:

hr.p:
1.Â Â Â Lavar las manos a menudo con agua y jabÃ³n. Si no hay agua y jabÃ³n disponibles, use un desinfectante de manos.
2.Â Â Â Cubrir nuestra boca y nariz al toser o estornudar. Toser o estornudar en nuestros codos es la mejor manera de hacerlo.
3.Â Â Â Evitar tocarse los ojos, la nariz o la boca ya que los gÃ©rmenes a menudo se propagan despuÃ©s de tocar algo contaminado y luego toca sus ojos, nariz o boca.
4.Â Â Â Evitar el contacto cercano con personas enfermas. Esto tambiÃ©n incluye nuestra responsabilidad de quedarnos en casa o que nuestros hijos se queden en casa si estÃ¡n enfermos.
5.Â Â Â Practicar distanciamiento social y evite las reuniones de 250 o mÃ¡s.

Tenga en cuenta que tenemos un excelente personal de limpieza que ya han estado haciendo mÃ¡s durante esta temporada de gripe tratando de garantizar que las Ã¡reas superficies u objetos estÃ¡n limpios y desinfectados regularmente.Â AdemÃ¡s, nuestros conductores de autobuses durante la semana pasada estaban desinfectando sus autobuses despuÃ©s de cada ruta.
Â
AdemÃ¡s, con las vacaciones de primavera acercÃ¡ndose, si planea viajar, solo le pedimos que conozca los lugares con recomendaciones de viaje especÃ­ficas del CDC.
Â
En conclusiÃ³n, sepa que mantendremos comunicaciÃ³n con nuestros expertos locales de salud. Si otra informaciÃ³n necesaria llega a estar disponible, nos aseguraremos de compartirlo con usted.
Â
Gracias,
Andy Hartley, Superintendente
